docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: They don't open spring training for nearly two weeks and the Boston Red Sox already have expended a season's worth of turbulent energy. The turmoil that has engulfed the team is, to a great extent, the result of an epidemic of foot-in-mouth disease. As soon as one player contracts it, another supplants him and becomes the focal point of the week.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

headline.main: Question Of the Week: Next Week; Are Red Sox Fans in For Another Fall?

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: John McNamara, the Red Sox manager, is worried about a potential conflict with his ace right-hander, Roger Clemens, in connection with selecting pitchers for this season's all-star team. So McNamara wants somebody else to pick the pitching staff, and he plans to discuss that idea with the league president, Bobby

docs.lead_paragraph: ''See that guy?'' said Edward McKechnie, pointing to a fellow Red Sox fan entering Yankee Stadium last night, a man looking rather like a walking Red Sox souvenir stand, with a pennant, baseball cap and T-shirt. ''He's history.'' Mr. McKechnie believes - ''absolutely!'' - in supporting his beloved Red Sox when they come to New York, but in a safe and sane manner. ''The problem,'' he said before his team's 7-2 victory, ''is that the Red Sox are big winners this year and these fans just coming out of the closet don't know they have to take precautions at Yankee Stadium. '' New York plays host this weekend to the Boston Red Sox, as perhaps only New York can. As usual in this ancient and often bitter rivalry, a good deal of the action is expected to take place in the stands.

headline.main: Take Them Out to the Ball Game (With Helmets)

docs.lead_paragraph: Haywood Sullivan, the man who runs the Boston Red Sox, sits in his office in Fenway Park these days, remembers how his team blew a 14-game lead to the New York Yankees and confesses: "I sit and stare, but I haven't come up with the answer yet."
docs.abstract: article on team official Haywood Sullivan, reflecting on final day loss of pennant, preparing for '79 season; illus (M)

headline.main: Red Sox Reflect; Sports of The Times

docs.lead_paragraph: "IT NEEDS a little sharpening-up," said Bowie Kuhn. "I'm not at all satisfied with it. I should give the clubs some clarification on that. I don't know how I'll do it but the $400,000 guideline needs some clarification."
docs.abstract: Red Smith article on Kuhn placing $400,000 limit on amount of money that can be included in any player trade; Kuhn illus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is Grand Circuit week in Goshen, N. Y., when the trotters and pacers come back to the peaceful little seat of Orange County and find it much the same as it was when Messenger, the gray progenitor of America's light harness horse, stood at stud there 171 years ago, or when Messenger's prepotent descendant, Hambletonian 10, was foaled in 1849.
